text: Patients who survive intubation often find themselves profoundly debilitated. They experience weakness, memory loss, anxiety, depression, and hallucinations, and have difficulty sleeping, walking, and talking. https://t.co/JbcvWqxqxc

name: NewYorker
text: "At this point, voting for Joe [Biden] is almost the equivalent of wearing a mask. This is what we need to do to get out of this," @desusnice says. "People say they’re having to choose between two evils, but, no: one person has killed 100,000 Americans." https://t.co/9la4c1ZiNp

name: NewYorker
text: A quirk of history has saddled American democracy with an idiosyncratic, fractured way of voting, @SueHalpernVT writes. Can we secure the voting process? https://t.co/aQRaf3Huxc

text:

name: NewYorker
text: When COVID-19 overran the U.S., the Army Corps of Engineers was determined to provide vital infrastructure quickly. Between late March and the end of June, the Corps built 38 alternate care facilities nationwide, adding more than 15,000 hospital beds. https://t.co/lTHVwiHqPJ

text: Whatever the reason—ostentatious littering, the mad desire for a furtive lockdown high—nitrous-oxide cannisters are ubiquitous in London this summer. https://t.co/exkmpiqnpd
